Just my $0.02..

Bloat is extremely common in Genetic Programming and I wou=
ld suspect that it
is for the same reason as Ken mention previously - expan=
sion of the genome
for the purpose of moving outside of local minima, ie, e=
xploration.

The methods to control it there is to assign a hard limit on t=
he size of the
tree - in this case a hard limit on maximum nodes.  I don't =
know if that's
such a good idea in this case as it presupposes that you kno=
w how big you
want your network.  Another method is to incorporate network =
complexity into
the fitness function such that you favor smaller genomes wi=
th the same
fitness.

-Kirk





On Wed, Jan 20, 2010 at 4:41 PM, Jeff Clun=
e <jclune@...> wrote:

>
>
> Thanks for your thoughts on this Ken.
>

It's a shame that non-deterministic fitness has such an adverse effect
> he=
re,
> given that many real problems are noisy, and that natural evolution h=
andles
> a ton of noise. I wonder if a lot of research has gone into solvin=
g this
> problem. I can't think of anything off the top of my head.
>
> I a=
m curious how general this phenomenon is. Does anyone else out there
> have=

> non-deterministic fitness functions? Do you see this sort of a bloat in =
the
> NEAT networks or HyperNEAT genomes?
>
> Kind regards,
> Jeff Clune

 Jeff, first, if fitness is stagnant, then the system should be increasing
=
> the
> > average number of nodes (though not necessarily the number of nod=
es in
> the
> > champ). In a stagnant situation, you do not have informatio=
n (i.e. a
> > gradient) suggesting which direction is right to go. Therefor=
e, the most
> > principled response is to expand your options while never p=
utting all
> your
> > eggs in one basket. When fitness is stagnant, we cann=
ot know if further
> > search within the currently dimensionality might eve=
ntually find a
> solution,
> > or if the current dimensionality is insuffic=
ient and contains no solution
> at
> > all. In the latter case, the number =
of nodes and connections would need
> to
> > ascend to higher dimensionalit=
y. Because we do not know which case we are
> in
> > when stagnation occurs=
, the best idea is to try both: Some species start
> > arriving with bigger=
 networks while others keep searching in the same old
> > spaces. Thus, we =
would expect the *range* of sizes to increase along with
> the
> > average =
size.
> >
> > Your situation with nondeterminism is probably somewhat simil=
ar, causing
> the
> > average size of solutions to go up because of stagnat=
ion. However,
> because
> > the champion will keep changing with the random=
ized evaluation, you will
> > observe this phenomenon in the champion itsel=
f. The more noisy it is, the
> > more it is probably observable (i.e. becau=
se the more "random" it is who
> > happens to look best at any given time, =
in effect leading to a kind of
> > sampling of the population through the c=
hampion).
> >
> > Of course, that may not be a complete explanation for the=
 steep angle of
> the
> > incline. I would guess that nondeterminism is als=
o causing a general
> > unhealthiness about the evolutionary process overal=
l. Nondeterminism is
> highly
> > destructive to evolutionary algorithms. T=
his issue is controversial (even
> > within my own group!) but my personal =
opinion is one should avoid
> > nondeterminism unless it is absolutely esse=
ntial. For example, you can
> choose
> > a random order of examples but the=
n subject everyone to the same random
> set -
> > a kind of "deterministic =
randomness." Of course, you are banking on the
> > impartiality of randomne=
ss to give you maximal generality, but it will
> often
> > be outweighed by=
 its unhealthy side effects on the population. So I'm
> > guessing that par=
t of the phenomenon is just a side-effect of an
> inconsistent
> > evaluati=
on scheme leading to relative chaos.
> >
> > There may also be more to it; =
it merits further investigation as well.
> >
> > ken

Just my $0.02..<br><br>Bloat is extremely common in Genetic Programming and=
 I would suspect that it is for the same reason as Ken mention previously -=
 expansion of the genome for the purpose of moving outside of local minima,=
 ie, exploration.=A0 <br>
<br>The methods to control it there is to assign =
a hard limit on the size of the tree - in this case a hard limit on maximum=
 nodes.=A0 I don't know if that's such a good idea in this case as =
it presupposes that you know how big you want your network.=A0 Another meth=
od is to incorporate network complexity into the fitness function such that=
 you favor smaller genomes with the same fitness.<br>
<br>-Kirk<br><br><br>=
<br><br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Wed, Jan 20, 2010 at 4:41 PM, Jef=
f Clune <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:jclune@...">jclune@msu.=
edu</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"bor=
der-left: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 0.8ex; padding-=
left: 1ex;">














<div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 25=
5);">
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>T=
hanks for your thoughts on this Ken.<br>
<br>
It's a shame that non-det=
erministic fitness has such an adverse effect here,<br>
given that many rea=
l problems are noisy, and that natural evolution handles<br>
a ton of noise=
. I wonder if a lot of research has gone into solving this<br>
problem. I c=
an't think of anything off the top of my head.<br>
<br>
I am curious ho=
w general this phenomenon is. Does anyone else out there have<br>
non-deter=
ministic fitness functions? Do you see this sort of a bloat in the<br>
NEAT=
 networks or HyperNEAT genomes?<br>
<br>
Kind regards,<br>
Jeff Clune<br>
<=
br>
Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University<br>
<a href=3D"mailto:=
jclune%40msu.edu" target=3D"_blank">jclune@...</a><br>
<a href=3D"http:=
//www.msu.edu/%7Ejclune" target=3D"_blank">www.msu.edu/~jclune</a><br>
<br>=

 CPPN node bloat<br>

> <br>
> Jeff, first, if fit=
ness is stagnant, then the system should be increasing the<br>
> average=
 number of nodes (though not necessarily the number of nodes in the<br>
&gt=
; champ).  In a stagnant situation, you do not have information (i.e. a<br>=

> gradient) suggesting which direction is right to go.  Therefore, the =
most<br>
> principled response is to expand your options while never put=
ting all your<br>
> eggs in one basket.  When fitness is stagnant, we ca=
nnot know if further<br>
> search within the currently dimensionality mi=
ght eventually find a solution,<br>
> or if the current dimensionality i=
s insufficient and contains no solution at<br>
> all.  In the latter cas=
e, the number of nodes and connections would need to<br>
> ascend to hig=
her dimensionality.  Because we do not know which case we are in<br>
> w=
hen stagnation occurs, the best idea is to try both:  Some species start<br=
>
> arriving with bigger networks while others keep searching in the sam=
e old<br>
> spaces.  Thus, we would expect the *range* of sizes to incre=
ase along with the<br>
> average size.  <br>
> <br>
> Your situati=
on with nondeterminism is probably somewhat similar, causing the<br>
> a=
verage size of solutions to go up because of stagnation.  However, because<=
br>
> the champion will keep changing with the randomized evaluation, yo=
u will<br>
> observe this phenomenon in the champion itself.  The more n=
oisy it is, the<br>
> more it is probably observable (i.e. because the m=
ore "random" it is who<br>
> happens to look best at any given=
 time, in effect leading to a kind of<br>
> sampling of the population t=
hrough the champion).<br>
> <br>
> Of course, that may not be a compl=
ete explanation for the steep angle of the<br>
> incline.  I would guess=
 that nondeterminism is also causing a general<br>
> unhealthiness about=
 the evolutionary process overall. Nondeterminism is highly<br>
> destru=
ctive to evolutionary algorithms.  This issue is controversial (even<br>
&g=
t; within my own group!) but my personal opinion is one should avoid<br>
&g=
t; nondeterminism unless it is absolutely essential.  For example, you can =
choose<br>
> a random order of examples but then subject everyone to the=
 same random set -<br>
> a kind of "deterministic randomness."=
  Of course, you are banking on the<br>
> impartiality of randomness to =
give you maximal generality, but it will often<br>
> be outweighed by it=
s unhealthy side effects on the population.  So I'm<br>
> guessing t=
hat part of the phenomenon is just a side-effect of an inconsistent<br>
&gt=
; evaluation scheme leading to relative chaos.<br>
> <br>
> There may=
 also be more to it; it merits further investigation as well.<br>
> <br>=

> ken <br>
> <br>
> <br>
> <br>
